flow.context: Zane Strickland is Director of Operations for West Aspen at Frias Properties — promoted from Property Manager in 2024, at the company since 2020. He owns turnover quality, guest readiness, and damage tracking across a big chunk of their 130+ luxury vacation rentals in Aspen and Snowmass. Frias runs on Streamline for PMS and work orders, expanded into Snowmass in 2023, and markets hospitality-level full-service care with dedicated housekeeping leadership (Manuel Nava, Isidra Santos). Ben Wolff (Managing Partner & GM) sits above him; Chris Longden (Director of Ops, East Aspen) is his peer. Strongest hook: Sam was just skiing in Jackson Hole last week — Zane lives and works in Aspen ski country and we're calling mid-peak season.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Zane — I was just out in Jackson Hole last week, ended up talking to a few property managers out there about their turnover workflows. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around?
opener.note: Feet-up-on-the-desk energy. You're a fellow ski guy calling mid-season — let the Jackson Hole line land before you give your name. Don't rush.

branches.label: Yes / I think so / Maybe
No / Who? / Doesn't ring a bell
Now's not a good time / I'm busy
What is this about? / Who are you with?

heard_yes.label: THEY'VE HEARD OF YOU
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone like you. What did you hear?
heard_yes.note: Let them talk. Whatever they say, use it as a bridge into discovery. Don't correct or re-pitch — follow their thread.

branches.label: They describe something positive or neutral
They're vague / 'not much'
They heard something skeptical

heard_no.label: HAVEN'T HEARD OF YOU
heard_no.say: Oh, I guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well — the reason for my call...
heard_no.note: Smile when you say this. Self-deprecating, then immediately pivot to the pain trigger. No pause between this line and the next node.

branches.label: Continue →

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — I know peak season in Aspen is insane right now. Would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again later this week? Maybe Thursday or Friday when things calm down a bit?
bad_timing.note: Acknowledge the season — he's flipping luxury units back to back right now. Be specific with callback days. If he gives you a time, lock it in and get off the phone.

branches.label: Sure, try me Thursday / Friday / gives a time
Just tell me real quick what it's about
No / Don't call back

reschedule.label: CALLBACK LOCKED
reschedule.say: Perfect — I'll try you Thursday. Appreciate it, Zane. Talk soon.
reschedule.note: Write down the exact day and time immediately. Don't pitch anything else. Get off the phone.

who_is_this.label: WHO IS THIS / WHAT'S THIS ABOUT
who_is_this.say: Yeah totally — I mean it is a cold call, I'll be honest. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out, and you can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit?
who_is_this.note: Honesty disarms. The '30 seconds + permission to hang up' line lowers their guard. If he says yes, go straight to pain trigger.

branches.label: Sure / Go ahead / 30 seconds
No / Not interested / I'm good

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED
permission_rejected.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you're already all set with how you're handling your turnover inspections?
permission_rejected.note: This isn't pushback — it's a genuine question. The split gives him two easy outs, and either one gives you information to work with.

branches.label: Bad timing / Caught me at a bad time
We're all set / Already have a process
Just not interested / Take me off the list

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER
pain_trigger.say: So I work with a few other operations directors at vacation rental companies in ski markets, and the thing I keep hearing — especially right now during peak season — is this: cleaners are flipping units back to back, snapping photos between every turn, but nobody actually has time to look through all of them. So what ends up happening is a guest checks into a place that's going for two or three grand a night, and there's a stain on the sofa or a crack in the countertop from the last guest — but nobody caught it in the photos. Now you're trying to figure out which guest caused it, the owner's calling you, and you're eating the cost. Does any of that sound familiar?
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE after 'does any of that sound familiar.' This is the most important silence in the call. Let Zane react. His response tells you exactly where to go next. Do not fill the silence.

branches.label: Yeah / That's exactly what happens / We deal with that
Sort of / We have a process but it's not perfect
Not really / We've got that handled
I don't have time for this / What are you selling?

warm_reaction.label: THEY FEEL THE PAIN
warm_reaction.say: Yeah — I figured with 130-plus units in a market like Aspen, that's gotta be a constant thing. So real quick — we built a tool that plugs into the photos your cleaners are already taking and uses AI to flag damage, missing items, staging issues automatically — before the next guest checks in. Instead of someone manually reviewing every set, the system catches it. Would you be open to taking a look sometime when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue?
warm_reaction.note: One sentence on the solution, then straight to the CTA. Don't over-explain how the AI works. If he says yes, book it NOW. If he starts asking questions, you're in discovery — stop pitching and start listening.

branches.label: Yeah sure / I'd take a look
How does it work? / Tell me more
Send me an email
I'm not the right person for this

neutral_reaction.label: LUKEWARM — THEY HAVE SOMETHING
neutral_reaction.say: Yeah, that makes sense — I'd honestly be surprised if you didn't have something in place with a portfolio your size. Out of curiosity, what does that look like right now? Are your cleaners documenting stuff through Streamline, or is it a separate workflow?
neutral_reaction.note: You KNOW they use Streamline for work orders — drop it casually to show you've done homework. This transitions into discovery. Listen for gaps in their process — that's your opening.

branches.label: They describe their process (photos in Streamline / manual review)
We use Breezeway / another dedicated tool
I don't want to get into it / Not interested

acknowledge_and_pivot.label: HEARD SOMETHING SKEPTICAL
acknowledge_and_pivot.say: Ah, fair enough — I'm curious what you heard. But honestly, the reason I'm reaching out is pretty straightforward. I've been talking to a few ops directors at companies similar to Frias, and there's one problem that keeps coming up around turnover photos and damage tracking. Can I give you the 30-second version?
acknowledge_and_pivot.note: Don't get defensive about whatever they heard. Acknowledge, redirect, and earn the 30 seconds.

branches.label: Sure / Go ahead
Not interested

discovery_current_process.label: DISCOVERY — CURRENT PROCESS
discovery_current_process.say: That's actually super helpful. So right now, when your team flips a unit on the West Aspen side — what does the photo and inspection piece look like? Are your cleaners documenting everything themselves, or do you have inspectors going behind them?
discovery_current_process.note: STOP PITCHING. You're in discovery now. Ask questions, take notes. Listen for: who takes photos, who reviews them, what tool they use, how many turnovers per week, what falls through the cracks.

branches.label: They describe the process in detail
We run it through Streamline / work orders
We don't really have a formal process / It's loose

discovery_streamline.label: DISCOVERY — STREAMLINE WORKFLOW
discovery_streamline.say: Oh nice — so you're running everything through Streamline. That's pretty common with operators I talk to. So when the photos come in, who's actually reviewing them? Is that you, or do Manuel and the housekeeping team handle that?
discovery_streamline.note: They use Streamline for PMS and work orders — confirmed. Manuel Nava and Isidra Santos are Housekeeping Managers. Dropping Manuel's name shows deep research. Dig into who actually reviews photos and where the bottleneck lives.

branches.label: I review them / My team reviews them
Housekeeping handles it / Manuel and Isidra
Honestly nobody reviews them closely

discovery_pain_points.label: DISCOVERY — DIG INTO PAIN
discovery_pain_points.say: Got it. And in peak season like right now — how many turnovers are you running per week across your West Aspen units? And when something does slip through — a damage that doesn't get caught — what does that look like for you? Who ends up getting the call from the owner?
discovery_pain_points.note: You want two things: (1) turnover volume so you can quantify the problem, (2) the emotional pain of what happens when things slip. If Zane says he personally gets owner calls, that's gold — he'll want this fixed.

branches.label: High volume / Things do slip through / I get the calls
We're pretty tight / Not many misses
That's really more of a housekeeping issue

discovery_no_process.label: DISCOVERY — NO FORMAL PROCESS
discovery_no_process.say: Yeah — that's actually really common. Most operators I talk to, the photos exist but nobody's systematically reviewing them until there's a problem and you're going back trying to figure out what happened after the fact. That's actually the exact gap we fill. We plug into the photos that are already being taken and automatically flag anything that looks off — damage, missing items, staging issues — before the next guest walks in. Would you be open to seeing what that looks like? Fifteen minutes, I can show you on some sample photos.
discovery_no_process.note: This is a green light. They have the problem and no solution. Pitch the meeting, not the product. Keep it short.

branches.label: Sure / Yeah let's look at it
Send me something first
I'd need to loop in someone else

discovery_existing_tool.label: DISCOVERY — THEY HAVE A TOOL
discovery_existing_tool.say: Oh nice — how's that been working for you? Are you finding it actually catches stuff proactively, or is it more of a documentation tool where you still need someone reviewing everything manually?
discovery_existing_tool.note: If they name a competitor (Breezeway, Properly, etc.), don't bash it. Ask how it's working. Most tools are documentation-first, not detection-first — that's RapidEye's differentiation.

branches.label: It's fine / Works well enough
It's mostly documentation / We still review manually
It's a pain / Not great

solution_and_cta.label: SOLUTION + MEETING ASK
solution_and_cta.say: That's exactly what I keep hearing. So what we built is basically an AI layer that sits on top of your existing photo workflow — your cleaners don't change anything they're doing — and it automatically reviews every photo, flags damage, missing items, anything out of place. You get a report before the next guest checks in instead of finding out after. Would you be open to taking a look? I can walk you through it in fifteen minutes — worst case you steal some ideas from what other ski-market PMs are doing with their turnover photos and we part as friends.
solution_and_cta.note: The 'worst case you steal some ideas' line is your safety net — makes the meeting feel low-risk. If he says yes, immediately propose a specific day and time.

branches.label: Sure / Yeah I'd be interested
Not right now / Maybe later
Send me an email
I'd need to loop someone else in

solution_and_cta_soft.label: SOFT CTA — THEY FEEL COVERED
solution_and_cta_soft.say: That's solid — sounds like you run a tight ship. I'll say this: what I keep hearing from ops directors who think they've got it locked down is they're surprised what the AI catches that their team didn't. Not because the team is bad — just because when you're flipping twenty units in a day, the human eye misses stuff. Would you be open to seeing it? Even just to benchmark against what you're already doing?
solution_and_cta_soft.note: Don't argue with 'we're pretty tight.' Reframe the meeting as a benchmark or sanity check, not a fix for a broken process.

branches.label: Sure / Can't hurt to look
Not right now / We're good
Send me something

objection_not_interested.label: NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: I totally get it. I should've assumed you'd be all set — otherwise you probably would've reached out yourself. Just so no one from my team cold calls you again — is it that turnover quality isn't really a problem you're focused on right now, or is it more that you just hate cold calls?
objection_not_interested.note: Agree first — surprise him by not pushing back. The split question gives him an easy out while keeping the door open. If it's 'hate cold calls,' pivot to email. If it's 'not focused on it,' you can ask who is.

branches.label: I just hate cold calls / Bad medium
Not a priority right now / We're covered
Not interested at all / Firm no

objection_have_process.label: WE ALREADY HAVE SOMETHING IN PLACE
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with 130-plus units you'd have to have something dialed in. I'd honestly be surprised if you didn't. Is it that you're fully covered and love what you've got, or is it more that switching anything mid-peak-season would just be a headache?
objection_have_process.note: This split is critical. 'Love what we've got' is rare — most people tolerate their process. 'Switching mid-season is a headache' means they're open but timing is wrong. That's a meeting you can book for after season.

branches.label: We're happy with what we have
It's more about timing / Can't switch mid-season
Honestly it works but it's not perfect

objection_no_budget.label: NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Nowadays it's harder to keep a tool, let alone buy something new. Just so I'm not wasting your time — is it that budget for this cycle is completely locked, or is it more that anything you try to buy has to go through a whole approval chain?
objection_no_budget.note: If budget is locked, pitch the test drive for future planning. If it's an approval chain, ask who approves — that's your path to Ben Wolff.

branches.label: Budget is locked / Nothing this year
Everything goes through Ben / through approval
It's just not a priority spend right now

timing_pitch.label: TIMING — POST-SEASON MEETING
timing_pitch.say: A hundred percent — mid-season is not the time to rip anything out. What if we did this: I shoot you a quick note now, and we block fifteen minutes for after mud season — maybe late April, early May — when you actually have headspace to think about next year's ops? That way you go into next season knowing what's out there.
timing_pitch.note: Aspen's off-season ('mud season') is typically late April through May. That's when ops leaders plan for the following year. Book it far out if you have to — a meeting on the calendar is a meeting on the calendar.

branches.label: Yeah that makes more sense / Sure
Just send me an email for now
Not interested even then

test_drive_pitch.label: TEST DRIVE — SELL THE FUTURE LOOK
test_drive_pitch.say: Totally respect that. Here's my thought though — you're probably not buying anything right now, and that's fine. But when budget or timing does free up, the folks who end up moving fast are the ones who already know what's on their shortlist. Would you be open to a quick look — not to buy, just so you know what's out there? If nothing else I can show you what other operators in ski markets are doing with their turnover photos. Fifteen minutes.
test_drive_pitch.note: This is your last clean shot at a meeting. The 'not to buy, just to know' framing removes all pressure. If he still says no, go to email or graceful exit.

branches.label: Sure / Fine, fifteen minutes
Send me an email instead
No thanks / Not for me

objection_send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
objection_send_email.say: Totally fair — I'll shoot something over today. One question before I do so it's not just another generic pitch sitting in your inbox — what would actually be most relevant for you? Is it more the damage detection side of things, or is it more about tracking cleaner and inspector consistency across your units?
objection_send_email.note: This question does two things: (1) gives you intel to tailor the email, (2) keeps him talking and shows you're thoughtful. Whatever he answers, use it in the follow-up.

branches.label: Damage detection / Catching issues
Cleaner performance / Consistency tracking
Just send whatever / I don't care

objection_send_email_warm.label: THEY HATE COLD CALLS — PIVOT TO EMAIL
objection_send_email_warm.say: Ha — totally fair, I hate getting them too. Tell you what, I'll send you a quick note with some context, and if it looks interesting you can grab time on my calendar whenever works for you. No more cold calls from me. What's the best email — is it Zane at Frias Properties dot com?
objection_send_email_warm.note: You already know his email is Zane@FriasProperties.com but confirming it builds a small moment of rapport and verifies it's still current. Keep it light and friendly.

branches.label: Yeah that's right / Confirms email
Gives a different email

email_confirm.label: CONFIRM EMAIL + SUGGEST TIME
email_confirm.say: Got it — I'll send that over today. And just so it doesn't die in your inbox, I'm gonna throw a time suggestion in there for next week. If it doesn't work, no worries — but at least you've got it. Appreciate you taking my call, Zane.
email_confirm.note: Always include a specific day and time in the email — 'next Tuesday at 2pm MT' beats 'whenever works.' Send the email within 10 minutes of hanging up. Subject line should reference the skiing or Aspen specifically.

not_right_person.label: NOT THE RIGHT PERSON
not_right_person.say: Totally get it — who on your team would typically own a decision around inspection tooling or turnover workflows? Is that more of a Ben Wolff conversation, or is there someone else I should be talking to?
not_right_person.note: Dropping Ben Wolff's name by name shows you've done research and makes the referral concrete. If Zane mentions Chris Longden or the housekeeping managers (Manuel Nava, Isidra Santos), note those names.

branches.label: Yeah, talk to Ben / That's a Ben decision
Talk to Chris Longden / My counterpart on the East side
Talk to housekeeping / Manuel / Isidra
I'm not sure / Won't give a name

referral_to_ben.label: REFERRAL — BEN WOLFF
referral_to_ben.say: Perfect — would you mind if I mentioned your name when I reach out to Ben? And is email or his direct line the better way to catch him?
referral_to_ben.note: You already have Ben's direct line (970-429-2435) and email (Ben@FriasProperties.com). Getting Zane's permission to name-drop is the real win — it turns the next call warm.

branches.label: Sure, mention my name / Here's how to reach him
Don't mention me / Just reach out on your own

referral_to_chris.label: REFERRAL — CHRIS LONGDEN
referral_to_chris.say: Chris Longden, right — the East Aspen operations director? Would you mind if I mentioned your name when I reach out?
referral_to_chris.note: Confirming Chris's name and title shows credibility. His direct line is 970-429-2436, email is CLongden@FriasProperties.com. Getting permission to name-drop is the goal.

branches.label: Yeah sure / Go ahead
Don't mention me / Just reach out

referral_to_housekeeping.label: REFERRAL — HOUSEKEEPING MANAGERS
referral_to_housekeeping.say: Got it — would that be Manuel Nava or Isidra? And would you mind if I mentioned you sent me their way?
referral_to_housekeeping.note: Manuel Nava (970-618-8433) and Isidra Santos (970-429-2425) are both Housekeeping Managers. They feel turnover photo pain most directly. A warm referral from Zane makes these calls much easier.

branches.label: Manuel / Isidra / Both — and confirms referral
Just reach out on your own

referral_confirm.label: CONFIRM REFERRAL + CLOSE
referral_confirm.say: Awesome — really appreciate that, Zane. I'll put something tailored together for them so it actually lands. Thanks for taking my call — and enjoy the rest of ski season out there.
referral_confirm.note: End on the skiing note — ties back to the opener. Send the referral outreach the same day while Zane's name is fresh. If he gave permission to name-drop, lead with that in the next call's opener.

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Awesome. I've got next week pulled up — how does Tuesday or Wednesday look? I'm thinking early afternoon your time, like one or two PM Mountain?
book_meeting.note: Be specific — two days, a time range. Don't say 'whenever works for you.' Mid-week early afternoon avoids the morning turnover crunch an ops director deals with during ski season.

branches.label: Tuesday works / Wednesday works / Gives a time
Later in the week / Different time
Actually let me think about it first

book_meeting_future.label: BOOK POST-SEASON MEETING
book_meeting_future.say: Perfect. How about the last week of April — say Wednesday April 29th, early afternoon? I'll send over a calendar invite right now so it's locked in, and I'll shoot you a reminder closer to the date.
book_meeting_future.note: Post-mud-season timing. Send the calendar invite immediately while still on the phone. Don't let it become 'I'll reach back out sometime' — get it on the calendar now.

branches.label: Sure / That works
Just email me then / I'll find time later

meeting_booked.label: MEETING CONFIRMED
meeting_booked.say: Locked in. I'll send the invite right now so you've got it. Really appreciate you taking my call, Zane — enjoy the rest of the season. Talk soon.
meeting_booked.note: STOP SELLING. The meeting is booked. Send the calendar invite within 60 seconds of hanging up. Include a one-line agenda and your Zoom link. Don't add pitch materials — you already won.

graceful_exit.label: GRACEFUL EXIT
graceful_exit.say: Totally understand. If anything changes, I'm easy to find — Sam Parks, RapidEye. Appreciate your time, Zane. Enjoy the snow out there.
graceful_exit.note: Don't burn the bridge. Log the call, note the objection and any intel he shared, and set a follow-up reminder for 60-90 days. Zane may be much more receptive after ski season winds down in April.
